title: Andrew Baldwin
text:
<a href="Captain">Captain</a> Andrew James Baldwin, MD, <a href="United%20States%20Navy">USN</a> (born February 5, 1977, <a href="Lancaster%2C%20Pennsylvania">Lancaster, Pennsylvania</a>, <a href="United%20States">USA</a>) is a <a href="United%20States%20Navy">US Naval Officer</a>, ironman triathlete, television personality, <a href="humanitarian">humanitarian</a>, and <a href="physician">physician</a>. Born and raised in Pennsylvania, he received his bachelor's degree from <a href="Duke%20University">Duke University</a> and his medical degree from <a href="UCSF">UCSF</a>.
He is best known for his appearances on the 10th season of the reality dating show "<a href="The%20Bachelor%20%28U.S.%20TV%20series%29">The Bachelor</a>" dubbed "". On November 13, 2007, he told <a href="Honolulu%2C%20Hawaii">Honolulu, Hawaii</a>'s <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a> TV affiliate <a href="KITV">KITV</a> that he was shortly to be deployed to Bahrain. "<a href="Marianas%20Variety">Marianas Variety</a>", Micronesia's leading newspaper, recorded that LCDR Andy Baldwin "is part of the <a href="Joint%20POW/MIA%20Accounting%20Command">Joint POW/MIA Accounting Command</a> (JPAC) team conducting recovery operations in Palau."
Early life and education.
Baldwin is the son of <a href="Roy%20E.%20Baldwin">Roy E. Baldwin</a>, a former two-term Pennsylvania State Representative (R-97th District), and Cynthia Laulani Baldwin, a high school mathematics teacher and he has a brother and sister. Baldwin graduated as <a href="valedictorian">valedictorian</a> of <a href="Manheim%20Township%20High%20School">Manheim Township High School</a>'s class of 1995. He worked as a <a href="paper%20boy">paper boy</a>, <a href="lifeguard">lifeguard</a>, and had his own lawn mowing business to earn money for college, saving $25,000 before graduating high school. During high school, he played <a href="basketball">basketball</a>, <a href="tennis">tennis</a>, <a href="American%20football">football</a>, <a href="baseball">baseball</a>, and was an <a href="All-American">All-American</a> swimmer. He was named <a href="ESPN">ESPN</a>'s National Scholar Athlete of the Year in 1995.
Baldwin graduated "<a href="magna%20cum%20laude">magna cum laude</a>" from <a href="Duke%20University">Duke University</a> in 1999 with a <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Science">Bachelor of Science</a> degree in <a href="biology">biology</a>. While at Duke, he was a varsity swimmer, brother of <a href="Pi%20Kappa%20Alpha">Pi Kappa Alpha</a>, and a <a href="Navy%20Reserve%20Officer%20Training%20Corps">Navy Reserve Officer Training Corps</a> <a href="midshipman">midshipman</a>.
Career.
Upon graduation, he was commissioned an <a href="Ensign%20%28rank%29">ensign</a> in the United States Navy and received a four-year <a href="Health%20Professions%20Scholarship%20Program">Navy Health Professions Scholarship</a> to attend the <a href="UCSF%20School%20of%20Medicine">University of California, San Francisco School of Medicine</a>, receiving his <a href="Doctor%20of%20Medicine">M.D.</a> in 2003. He subsequently completed an <a href="Medical%20intern%23United%20States">internship</a> in <a href="general%20surgery">general surgery</a> at the <a href="Naval%20Medical%20Center%20San%20Diego">Naval Medical Center San Diego</a>, in 2004, and was a medical officer for Naval Special Warfare Group Three in Coronado from June to December 2004. He completed the Navy Undersea Medicine Training Institute and Navy Dive School in June 2005. In July 2005, he was given a three-year assignment as a member of the <a href="Navy%20Medical%20Corps">Navy Medical Corps</a> to serve as Diving <a href="Medical%20Officer">Medical Officer</a> for Mobile Diving and Salvage Unit One in <a href="Pearl%20Harbor">Pearl Harbor</a>, <a href="Oahu">Oahu</a>, <a href="Hawaii">Hawaii</a>.
Baldwin transferred from Hawaii to Washington, D.C. in April 2008 where he is working as a <a href="Navy%20medicine%20advocate">Navy medicine advocate</a> at the <a href="Bureau%20of%20Medicine%20and%20Surgery">Bureau of Medicine and Surgery</a>. In January 2009, Baldwin began working as assistant to the acting U.S. Surgeon General, RADM <a href="Steven%20Galson">Steven Galson</a> on his "Healthy Youth for a Healthy Future" initiative combating childhood overweight and obesity. In March 2009, Baldwin was selected as a finalist for the White House Fellows program. Baldwin is a Board Certified Family Physician and an MPH Graduate Student at the Johns Hopkins School of Public Health.
Humanitarian efforts.
Baldwin was awarded Humanitarian of the Year by Competitor Magazine at the Competitor Sports Awards. He was named to Outside magazine's top 100 influential people of the world list in 2006, and to the Washington D.C. Most Influential People under 40 List in 2009.
Baldwin was awarded Triathlete Magazine Humanitarian of 2007 by Triathlete Magazine. Baldwin was also placed on Outside magazine's list of the world's most influential people for the humanitarian work he did in Laos on a military mission where he treated over 600 Laotians in remote mountain villages for ailments such as malaria, dengue fever, parasites, and malnutrition. Baldwin also volunteered at the Aloha Medical Mission where he treated patients, free of charge, for various ailments.
Baldwin participated in ABC's Extreme Makeover Home Edition in building a new home for the Akana family in Hawaii.
Baldwin established The Got Your Back Network, a nonprofit organization that raises money to support the families of the service men and women who gave their lives while serving their country. 100% of the funds raised fund an endowment to provide financial support for applicant families: education, emergencies and medicine.
Baldwin is now focusing on more humanitarian works. He has been involved in numerous charities including the TV Special Stand Up to Cancer, winning the Malibu Triathlon raising money for the Children's Hospital Los Angeles, <a href="http%3A//www.bestbuddies.org">Best Buddies</a>, <a href="http%3A//www.snowballexpress.org">Snowball Express</a>, etc.
"The Bachelor".
Before being picked for The Bachelor, Baldwin was featured as an eligible California Bachelor in <a href="Cosmopolitan%20magazine">Cosmopolitan magazine</a> in 2005.
The 10th season of the show, "", premiered Monday, April 2, 2007 on the <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a> television network. Baldwin proposed to <a href="Tessa%20Horst">Tessa Horst</a> on the season finale, which aired May 21, 2007. She accepted his proposal, despite some claims in the media that she had not. Eight months after the final episode, Horst broke up with Baldwin when he was on deployment in the Pacific.
In June 2008, People Magazine named Andy Baldwin one of its hottest bachelors for 2008.
Other projects.
Honolulu Mayor Mufi Hannemann officially declared October 12 as Andy Baldwin Youth Fitness Day in the City and County of Honolulu. Dr. Baldwin is dedicated to educate and inspire children on the importance of healthy living.
In October 2009, Baldwin led a Health Ride across the state of Pennsylvania with his father speaking at elementary schools about the importance of physical activity.
Commander Baldwin is the founder of Got Your Back Network, an organization that assists military families who have lost a spouse or parent in Operation Iraqi Freedom or Operation Enduring Freedom. The goal of Got Your Back Network is to "give comfort, answer a special need, offer guidance and bring a brighter day to these families."
In June 2010 Baldwin made an appearance on the premiere of <a href="Top%20Chef">Top Chef</a> based in Washington, D.C.
On May 30, 2010 Baldwin ran 56 miles in South Africa, the Comrades Ultramarathon, as key member of Team World Vision securing sponsorships for children in need in Africa, Haiti, and other underdeveloped countries.
On February 1, 2011 Baldwin was named National Ambassador for the ING Kids Rock running program which gets kids involved in running and helps fight childhood obesity.
Triathlons.
Baldwin has been named to the All-Navy triathlon team five times, been a three-time U.S.A. Triathlon All-American, and competed internationally in numerous Half-Ironman and Ironman events. He is an eight-time Ironman finisher. In addition, he completed the 2013 New York City Marathon with a time of 3:18:13.
In 2015 Challenge Family Triathlons announced its partnership with Dr. Andy Baldwin. He will serve as an ambassador for the brand and compete in Challenge Family Americas races Challenge Family Americas board member Charlie Patten insists, “Andy is the real deal – a humanitarian and health care provider who serves his country and the world at large with generosity of heart and an indomitable spirit, lending a caring hand to US veterans and delivering critical medical care to those in need around the world.
